text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Do you guys ever have
cravings for dim sum?

Well, I do, so I
thought I would show you

how to make dim sum-style
pork spare ribs.

In Mandarin, we call
this dish pai gu,

and the bite-sized
riblets are marinated it

in a black bean sauce,
making this super-flavorful
and delicious.

And while it only takes
30 minutes to marinate,

you can actually marinate
this the night before

and have dim sum-style
pork spare ribs
ready for the next morning.

So here's what we'll
need to get started.

Start with half a pound
of pork spare ribs.

I'm using spare rib tips
cut into one inch pieces.

Then put those into a bowl
and add the ingredients
for our marinade.

We'll need one tablespoon
each of rice wine,

cornstarch and water,
half a teaspoon

of black beans or black
bean garlic sauce,

one teaspoon each of cane sugar,
sesame oil, and regular cooking

oil, half a teaspoon of
freshly grated ginger,

quarter teaspoon of
salt, and finally a dash
for two of white pepper.

Mix the ingredients
until well combined,

and let it marinate for
at least 30 minutes.

When the marinade
is almost ready,

slice about half a
jalapeno or red pepper

to give our spare ribs a bit of
spiciness and a dash of color.

Add this to our
marinade, and mix well

before transferring to small
plates or bowls for steaming.
Now it's time to cook.

Bring some water to a boil and
steam the dish of spare ribs

for 30 to 45 minutes,
or until well done
and the meat is tender.

After 30 to 45 minutes,
your spare ribs

are ready to serve hot with
rice or other dim sum goodies.

So that's how you make my dim
sum style spare ribs at home.

Once you get the marinade going,
everything else is super easy.

Now, if you're serving
this dim sum style,

I'd like to recommend some
other recipes you might

be interested in, like
my green onion pancakes
or even turnip cakes.

Or you can just serve this
with a bowl of hot rice.

Either way, it's
super easy to make,

and I'm sure you'll
be surprised at how

delicious homemade
spare ribs can taste.
I'm Angel.

I hope you guys
enjoyed this video.

Let me know in
the comments below

if you would like to see
more dim sum-style recipes.

And until then, I will
see you guys soon.
Bye!
[MUSIC PLAYING]
